com.reactivecascade.functional

Class ImmutableValue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.reactivecascade.functional.ImmutableValue<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    IGettable<T>, ISafeGettable<T>

    public class ImmutableValue<T>
extends Object
implements ISafeGettable<T>
    This can be useful for referring in a lambda expression to the the lambda expression.

    This can also be useful for removing all references to an intermediate from such that is may be garbage collected if needed. Intermediate values in a active chain may be consuming a lot of memory. In asynchronous functional chains based on RunnableAltFuture, dereference of intermediate values when going on to the next function, but only in production builds.

    Note that there is no mutator method which allows to re-enter the initial IGettable.VALUE_NOT_AVAILABLE state once it is lost. Thus one can not abuse the system to make an immutable mutable by moving back through this intermediate state. Once you leave the temple, you can never go back.

    Note that null is not a permissible from

    This uses a free thread model (any calling thread is used for all chained functions). This is a main difference from the similar SettableAltFuture which forces the specified evaluation thread group.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ImmutableValue

        public ImmutableValue()
        Create but do not yet set the from of an underlying AtomicReference

        You can use this object as a placeholder until an asynchronous function result is finally set.

        You can also attach code which will run when the from is set. See then(IAction) and then(IActionOne)

      • ImmutableValue

        public ImmutableValue(@NonNull
                      T value)
        This constructor creates and initialized the from to its final from.

        It can be useful to create for example default values.

        Parameters:
        value - the value to immediately set

      • ImmutableValue

        public ImmutableValue(@Nullable
                      IActionR<T> action)

    • Method Detail

      • then

        @NonNull
public ImmutableValue<T> then(@NonNull
                                       IActionOne<T> action)
        Add an action which will be run when set(Object) is called.

        If the from is already set(Object), the passed mOnFireAction will be run immediately and synchronously.

        Returns:
        this

public ImmutableValue<T> then(@NonNull

        Add an action which will be run when set(Object) is called.

        If the from is already set(Object), the passed mOnFireAction will be run immediately and synchronously.

        Returns:

      • isSet

        public final boolean isSet()
        Check if the immutable from has been asserted yet.

        Note that if you think you need this for your core logic, you may want to ask yourself if you can be better served by using the dependency mechanism of AbstractAltFuture.then(IAltFuture) and similar calls. It is often better to let the preconditions for a get() be set by the functional chain. If still needed, you may inserting your own atomic or non-atomic logic such as 

         
     if (!immutableValue.isSet()) {
        immutableValue.set(from); // Not thread save. This will throw an IllegalStateException if someone else set the from between the previous line and this line
     }
        Returns:
        true if the value is already asserted

      • get

        @CallSuper
 @NonNull
public T get()
        Get the from, or throw IllegalStateException if you are getting the from before it has been set.

        Generally you want to use this method instead of safeGet() when you can use dependency mechanisms properly. If you think have problems, ask if you should be doing some of your logic in a .subscribe() clause to guarantee the execution order.

        Specified by:
        get in interface IGettable<T>
        Returns:
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the supplied lazy evaluation IAction throws an error during evaluation

      • safeGet

        @CallSuper
 @NonNull
public T safeGet()
        Get the from, or return null if the from is not yet set.

        Usually you will have a better design with get() instead. This is fine to use if other parts of your application is reactive and will update the from again when it has been finally set.

        Specified by:
        safeGet in interface ISafeGettable<T>
        Returns:
        the from, or null if the from has not yet been determined

      • set

        @CallSuper
 @NonNull
public T set(@NonNull
                                  T value)
        Set the from.

        If this atomic mOnFireAction succeeds, any then(IActionOne) actions will also be run synchronously. This is a fairly low-level class which is used by other classes and for practical reasons it violates the "always asynchronous" assumption. Traditional. Sorry. :)

        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:

      • toString

        @CallSuper
 @NonNull
public String toString()
        Return the current from of the immutable from if possible

        In other cases marker text "(ImmutableValue not yet set)" will be returned. If you see this text, consider using a then(IActionOne) mOnFireAction to make your logic run when this from is set.

        Specified by:
        toString in interface IGettable<T>
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        the string representation, or "Value not available" if not yet determined and can not be determined by an on-get action
